newsitem.title: CANADA: BHP says diamond mine to cost C$900 million.
newsitem.headline: BHP says diamond mine to cost C$900 million.

text.p: Australia's Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd said Friday that its Lac de Gras diamond mine in Canada's Arctic is projected to cost C$900 million by the time it goes into production in the second half of 1998.

Jim Excell, BHP's manager for the project, told reporters that figure includes C$200 million spent so far, partly on exploration costs. A further C$700 million will be spent to develop the mine. BHP has 51 percent of the project and Dia Met Minerals Ltd of Canada has 29 percent.
BHP expects to spend about C$30 million a month, Excell said. The company previously put the cost of the mine project at C$860 million.
Canada's federal government granted final approval to the diamond mine earlier at a ceremony in Yellowknife.
Clarifying an earlier comment, Excell said full production was expected between June and December 1998.

Preliminary construction work has already started and is expected to get underway in earnest next summer. BHP hopes to receive a water license in early to mid-December and an updated land use permit next April, he said.

Don Morin, premier of the Northwest Territories, said BHP is supporting a plan to establish a valuation center for the diamonds in the Northwest Territories. The issue has been a politically sensitive one with northerners arguing that they should reap downstream spin-off benefits from the project.
"We have a commitment it will happen in the north...These diamonds are coming from our land," he said.

Ron Irwin, the federal minister responsible for the North, said a final decision had not yet been made but he hopes the valuation center will end up in the North. "Cost factors" will determine the final decision, he said.
